coredata.dc:title: The orientation of the antibiotic peptide maculatin 1.1 in DMPG and DMPC lipid bilayers. Support for a pore-forming mechanism

coredata.dc:description: AbstractMaculatin 1.1 is an antimicrobial peptide isolated from the Australian tree frog Litoria genimaculata that adopts an amphipathic, Î±-helical structure in solution. Its orientation and conformation when incorporated to pre-formed DMPG (1,2-dimyristoyl-sn-glycero-3-phosphoglycerol) and DMPC (1,2-dimyristoyl-sn-glycero-3-phosphocholine) vesicles was determined using polarised Fourier transform infraredâ??attenuated total reflection infrared and deuterium exchange experiments. For DMPG membranes, our results show insertion of â?¼70% of the maculatin 1.1 molecules, with an angle of insertion of approximately 35Â° to the membrane normal and with a predominant Î±-helical structure. These results suggest that maculatin 1.1 acts through a pore-forming mechanism to lyse bacterial membranes. A similar degree of insertion in DMPG (65%) and Î±-helical structure was observed for a biologically inactive, less amphipathic maculatin 1.1 analogue, P15A, although the helix tilt was found to be greater (46Â°) than for maculatin 1.1. Similar experiments performed using DMPC liposomes showed poor insertion, less than 5%, for both maculatin 1.1 and its analogue. In addition, the shape of the amide I band in these samples is consistent with Î±-helix, Î²-structure and disordered structures being present in similar proportion. These results clearly show that maculatin 1.1 inserts preferentially in negatively charged membranes (DMPG) which mimic the negatively charged membrane of Gram-positive bacteria. We attribute the high percentage of insertion of the biologically inactive analogue in DMPG to the fact that its concentration on the membrane surface in our experiments is likely to be much higher than that found in physiological conditions.

Fax: (65)-8968032</ce:text></ce:correspondence></ce:author-group><ce:date-received xmlns:ce=&quot;http://www.elsevier.com/xml/common/dtd&quot; day=&quot;6&quot; month=&quot;12&quot; year=&quot;2001&quot;></ce:date-received><ce:date-accepted xmlns:ce=&quot;http://www.elsevier.com/xml/common/dtd&quot; day=&quot;13&quot; month=&quot;12&quot; year=&quot;2001&quot;></ce:date-accepted><ce:abstract xmlns:ce=&quot;http://www.elsevier.com/xml/common/dtd&quot; class=&quot;author&quot;><ce:section-title>Abstract</ce:section-title><ce:abstract-sec><ce:simple-para view=&quot;all&quot;>Maculatin 1.1 is an antimicrobial peptide isolated from the Australian tree frog <ce:italic>Litoria genimaculata</ce:italic> that adopts an amphipathic, Î±-helical structure in solution. Its orientation and conformation when incorporated to pre-formed DMPG (1,2-dimyristoyl-<ce:italic>sn</ce:italic>-glycero-3-phosphoglycerol) and DMPC (1,2-dimyristoyl-<ce:italic>sn</ce:italic>-glycero-3-phosphocholine) vesicles was determined using polarised Fourier transform infraredâ??attenuated total reflection infrared and deuterium exchange experiments. For DMPG membranes, our results show insertion of â?¼70% of the maculatin 1.1 molecules, with an angle of insertion of approximately 35Â° to the membrane normal and with a predominant Î±-helical structure. These results suggest that maculatin 1.1 acts through a pore-forming mechanism to lyse bacterial membranes. A similar degree of insertion in DMPG (65%) and Î±-helical structure was observed for a biologically inactive, less amphipathic maculatin 1.1 analogue, P15A, although the helix tilt was found to be greater (46Â°) than for maculatin 1.1. Similar experiments performed using DMPC liposomes showed poor insertion, less than 5%, for both maculatin 1.1 and its analogue. In addition, the shape of the amide I band in these samples is consistent with Î±-helix, Î²-structure and disordered structures being present in similar proportion. These results clearly show that maculatin 1.1 inserts preferentially in negatively charged membranes (DMPG) which mimic the negatively charged membrane of Gram-positive bacteria. We attribute the high percentage of insertion of the biologically inactive analogue in DMPG to the fact that its concentration on the membrane surface in our experiments is likely to be much higher than that found in physiological conditions.</ce:simple-para></ce:abstract-sec></ce:abstract><ce:keywords xmlns:ce=&quot;http://www.elsevier.com/xml/common/dtd&quot; class=&quot;keyword&quot;><ce:section-title>Keywords</ce:section-title><ce:keyword><ce:text>Peptide antibiotic</ce:text></ce:keyword><ce:keyword><ce:text>Attenuated total reflection</ce:text></ce:keyword><ce:keyword><ce:text>Fourier transform infrared</ce:text></ce:keyword><ce:keyword><ce:text>1,2-Dimyristoyl-<ce:italic>sn</ce:italic>-glycero-3-phosphocholine</ce:text></ce:keyword><ce:keyword><ce:text>1,2-Dimyristoyl-<ce:italic>sn</ce:italic>-glycero-3-phosphoglycerol</ce:text></ce:keyword><ce:keyword><ce:text>Maculatin 1.1</ce:text></ce:keyword><ce:keyword><ce:text>Phospholipid membrane</ce:text></ce:keyword><ce:keyword><ce:text><ce:italic>Litoria genimaculata</ce:italic></ce:text></ce:keyword></ce:keywords><ce:keywords xmlns:ce=&quot;http://www.elsevier.com/xml/common/dtd&quot; class=&quot;abr&quot;><ce:section-title>Abbreviations</ce:section-title><ce:keyword><ce:text>ATR, attenuated total reflection infrared</ce:text></ce:keyword><ce:keyword><ce:text>DMPC, 1,2-dimyristoyl-<ce:italic>sn</ce:italic>-glycero-3-phosphocholine</ce:text></ce:keyword><ce:keyword><ce:text>DMPG, 1,2-dimyristoyl-<ce:italic>sn</ce:italic>-glycero-3-phosphoglycerol</ce:text></ce:keyword><ce:keyword><ce:text>FTIR, Fourier transform infrared</ce:text></ce:keyword><ce:keyword><ce:text>NMR, nuclear magnetic resonance</ce:text></ce:keyword><ce:keyword><ce:text>FSD, Fourier self-deconvoluted</ce:text></ce:keyword></ce:keywords></head><body><ce:sections xmlns:ce=&quot;http://www.elsevier.com/xml/common/dtd&quot;><ce:section view=&quot;all&quot;><ce:label>1</ce:label><ce:section-title>Introduction</ce:section-title><ce:para view=&quot;all&quot;>Many organisms employ antibiotic peptides as a defence mechanism to complement their existing immune systems <ce:cross-ref refid=&quot;BIB1&quot;>[1]</ce:cross-ref>. Amphibian skin is one of the sources of these peptides <ce:cross-ref refid=&quot;BIB2&quot;>[2]</ce:cross-ref>. One well-studied example is the magainin family of peptides isolated from the south African clawed frog <ce:italic>Xenopus laevis</ce:italic> <ce:cross-ref refid=&quot;BIB3&quot;>[3]</ce:cross-ref>. The members of this family of peptides are typically 21â??26 residues long and possess antibiotic, anti-fungal and tumouricidal activity <ce:cross-ref refid=&quot;BIB4&quot;>[4]</ce:cross-ref>. Two-dimensional solution nuclear magnetic resonance (2D-NMR) spectroscopy has been used to show that these peptides adopt an Î±-helical conformation in membrane-mimicking solvents and in phospholipid micelles <ce:cross-refs refid=&quot;BIB5 BIB6&quot;>[5,6]</ce:cross-refs>, whilst physico-chemical studies have shown that they interact with, and disrupt the integrity of, bacterial membranes <ce:cross-refs refid=&quot;BIB7 BIB8&quot;>[7,8]</ce:cross-refs>. Evidence supporting that they act by interacting directly with the membranes via a general morphological conformation <ce:cross-ref refid=&quot;BIB9&quot;>[9]</ce:cross-ref> and not by binding to a specific cell receptor comes from the finding that synthetic all-<ce:small-caps>D</ce:small-caps>-amino acid magainin has the same biological activity as natural all-<ce:small-caps>L</ce:small-caps>-amino acid magainin <ce:cross-ref refid=&quot;BIB9&quot;>[9]</ce:cross-ref>.</ce:para><ce:para view=&quot;all&quot;>Two mechanisms of bactericidal action have been proposed: the â??channelâ?? mechanism and the â??carpetâ?? mechanism (see <ce:cross-ref refid=&quot;BIB10&quot;>[10]</ce:cross-ref> for a review). According to the â??channelâ?? mechanism, peptide monomers insert perpendicularly to the bilayer, rearranging and then forming a transmembrane pore. This interferes with the mechanism of osmo-regulation in the cell, causing an uncontrolled flux of ions and solutes into and out of the cytoplasm, killing the bacteria <ce:cross-ref refid=&quot;BIB11&quot;>[11]</ce:cross-ref>. In the alternative â??carpetâ?? mechanism, a peptide aggregate binds parallel to the bilayer surface via electrostatic interactions. This causes membrane thinning, eventually leading to membrane disruption and cell death <ce:cross-ref refid=&quot;BIB10&quot;>[10]</ce:cross-ref>. For example, solid-state NMR and attenuated total reflection infraredâ??Fourier transform infrared (ATRâ??FTIR) studies on the magainin peptides have shown that they orient parallel to phospholipid bilayers <ce:cross-refs refid=&quot;BIB12 BIB13&quot;>[12,13]</ce:cross-refs>, a conformation that is consistent with the â??carpetâ?? mechanism. Melittin, in contrast, a 26-residue pore-forming peptide isolated from bee venom, was found to adopt a transmembrane orientation <ce:cross-ref refid=&quot;BIB14&quot;>[14]</ce:cross-ref>, i.e. perpendicular to the membrane plane, in phospholipid bilayers.</ce:para><ce:para view=&quot;all&quot;>We have attempted herein to assign either of these mechanisms to maculatin 1.1, an antimicrobial peptide (GLFGV LAKVA AHVVP AIAEH F-NH<ce:inf loc=&quot;post&quot;>2</ce:inf>) isolated from the skin glands of the Australian tree frog <ce:italic>Litoria genimaculata</ce:italic> <ce:cross-ref refid=&quot;BIB15&quot;>[15]</ce:cross-ref>. Previous circular dichroism and NMR studies revealed that it adopts an amphipathic Î±-helical conformation, both in the membrane-mimetic solvent 2,2,2-trifluoroethanol and in phospholipid micelles <ce:cross-ref refid=&quot;BIB16&quot;>[16]</ce:cross-ref>. When in a helical conformation, the length of maculatin 1.1, obtained from solution NMR studies, is approximately 30 Ã? <ce:cross-ref refid=&quot;BIB16&quot;>[16]</ce:cross-ref>, which is also the average thickness of a bacterial membrane <ce:cross-ref refid=&quot;BIB17&quot;>[17]</ce:cross-ref>. The length of maculatin 1.1 is therefore consistent with a â??channelâ?? mechanism of membrane interaction and lysis. Further, we have shown previously that maculatin 1.1 is not active against Gram-negative bacteria <ce:cross-ref refid=&quot;BIB16&quot;>[16]</ce:cross-ref>. As peptides which form oligomers upon membrane binding (a prerequisite condition for channel formation) do not readily cross the outer membrane of Gram-negative bacteria <ce:cross-ref refid=&quot;BIB10&quot;>[10]</ce:cross-ref>, this also would seem to suggest that the mechanism of action is via formation of a channel. If maculatin were acting via the â??carpetâ?? mechanism, one would expect the peptide to possess activity against both Gram-positive and Gram-negative bacteria <ce:cross-ref refid=&quot;BIB30&quot;>[30]</ce:cross-ref>.</ce:para><ce:para view=&quot;all&quot;>We have tested the hypothesis that maculatin 1.1 forms a channel using polarised ATRâ??FTIR to determine the orientation of the peptide when incorporated into DMPG (1,2-dimyristoyl-<ce:italic>sn</ce:italic>-glycero-3-phosphoglycerol) and DMPC (1,2-dimyristoyl-<ce:italic>sn</ce:italic>-glycero-3-phosphocholine) phospholipid vesicles. ATRâ??FTIR allows the helix tilt to be obtained from the dichroic ratios of the bands that originate from certain peptidic amide vibrations, amide I (Cî??O stretching) or amide A (Nâ??H stretching). In addition, ATRâ??FTIR allows the percentage of insertion in the membrane to be calculated, by measuring the amide I/amide II ratio before and after exposure to D<ce:inf loc=&quot;post&quot;>2</ce:inf>O. Clear support for either mechanism of action, â??channelâ?? or â??carpetâ??, can thus be derived simply measuring the orientation of the peptides relative to the membrane normal.</ce:para><ce:para view=&quot;all&quot;>DMPG, an anionic phospholipid, was chosen as a model system for the membranes of typical Gram-positive bacteria because their outer membrane leaflets are composed largely of anionic phospholipids such as phosphatidylglycerol, diphosphatidylglycerol and acidic polysaccharides (lipo-teichoic acids) <ce:cross-refs refid=&quot;BIB17 BIB18&quot;>[17,18]</ce:cross-refs>. DMPC, a zwitterionic phospholipid was used as a model for mammalian cell membranes. The behaviour of a maculatin 1.1 analogue, P15A, that possesses no antibiotic activity <ce:cross-ref refid=&quot;BIB16&quot;>[16]</ce:cross-ref> was also tested in the presence of either type of lipidic membrane.</ce:para></ce:section><ce:section id=&quot;SEC2&quot; view=&quot;all&quot;><ce:label>2</ce:label><ce:section-title>Materials and methods</ce:section-title><ce:section view=&quot;all&quot;><ce:label>2.1</ce:label><ce:section-title>Materials</ce:section-title><ce:para view=&quot;all&quot;>Maculatin 1.1 and the analogue P15A were purchased (&gt;95% purity) from Chiron Mimotopes (Vic., Australia) and were used without further purification. DMPG and DMPC were purchased from Aldrich (UK).</ce:para></ce:section><ce:section view=&quot;all&quot;><ce:label>2.2</ce:label><ce:section-title>Sample preparation</ce:section-title><ce:para view=&quot;all&quot;>DMPG or DMPC small unilamellar vesicles (100 Î¼l, 18.64 mg/ml) were prepared by extrusion <ce:cross-ref refid=&quot;BIB19&quot;>[19]</ce:cross-ref> through a polycarbonate filter (50 nm pore diameter). The peptide (100 Î¼l, 1 mg/ml) was then added to the solution, resulting in a peptide:lipid ratio of â?¼1:60 (mol/mol). The resultant mixture was swirled gently and applied onto a trapezoidal germanium internal reflection element (50 mm Ã? 2 mm Ã? 20 mm). Bulk water was removed using a dry nitrogen stream. For hydration under D<ce:inf loc=&quot;post&quot;>2</ce:inf>O and H/D exchange experiments, spectra were collected after flushing the interior of the sample cell with D<ce:inf loc=&quot;post&quot;>2</ce:inf>O-saturated nitrogen, obtained by bubbling dry nitrogen through two compartments containing D<ce:inf loc=&quot;post&quot;>2</ce:inf>O for 4 h.</ce:para></ce:section><ce:section view=&quot;all&quot;><ce:label>2.3</ce:label><ce:section-title>Polarised ATRâ??FTIR measurements</ce:section-title><ce:para view=&quot;all&quot;>ATRâ??FTIR spectra were obtained from a Nicolet Magna 560 spectrometer (Madison, WI, USA) purged with N<ce:inf loc=&quot;post&quot;>2</ce:inf> and equipped with a MCT detector cooled with liquid nitrogen. Infrared spectra were measured with a 25-reflections ATR accessory from Graseby Specac (Kent, UK) and a wire grid polariser (0.25 Î¼m, Graseby Specac). A total of 1000 interferograms were collected using either parallel or perpendicular polarised light at a resolution of 4 cm<ce:sup loc=&quot;post&quot;>â??1</ce:sup>. The spectra were averaged and processed with one-point zero-filling and Happâ??Genzel apodisation.</ce:para></ce:section><ce:section view=&quot;all&quot;><ce:label>2.4</ce:label><ce:section-title>Analysis of ATRâ??FTIR data</ce:section-title><ce:para view=&quot;all&quot;>Spectra were collected either after bulk water removal or after hydration with D<ce:inf loc=&quot;post&quot;>2</ce:inf>O. In the first case, the dichroic ratios, <ce:italic>R</ce:italic><ce:sup loc=&quot;post&quot;>ATR</ce:sup>, of the amide I band (due to Cî??O stretching) and that corresponding to the band at 2850 cm<ce:sup loc=&quot;post&quot;>â??1</ce:sup>, due to the symmetric methylene stretching of the lipid, were recorded. In the second case, after hydration with D<ce:inf loc=&quot;post&quot;>2</ce:inf>O, the dichroic ratio of the amide A band (due to Nâ??H stretching) was also recorded. Dichroic ratios were calculated as the ratio between the integrated absorptions collected with parallel and perpendicular polarised light.</ce:para><ce:para view=&quot;all&quot;>To measure the amide I dichroic ratio, the amide I band was Fourier self-deconvoluted (FSD) with a full-width at a half-height of 15 cm<ce:sup loc=&quot;post&quot;>â??1</ce:sup> and an enhancement factor <ce:italic>k</ce:italic> of 2.0, always below the logarithm of the signal-to-noise ratio <ce:cross-ref refid=&quot;BIB20&quot;>[20]</ce:cross-ref>. Peak integration was performed on these FSD spectra from 1670 to 1645 cm<ce:sup loc=&quot;post&quot;>â??1</ce:sup>. For the amide A band and the band at 2850 cm<ce:sup loc=&quot;post&quot;>â??1</ce:sup>, integration was performed without FSD from 3400 to 3200 cm<ce:sup loc=&quot;post&quot;>â??1</ce:sup> and from 2890 to 2800 cm<ce:sup loc=&quot;post&quot;>â??1</ce:sup>, respectively.</ce:para><ce:para view=&quot;all&quot;>The order parameters were calculated as previously <ce:cross-ref refid=&quot;BIB21&quot;>[21]</ce:cross-ref>. First, the order parameters for the helix <ce:italic>S</ce:italic><ce:inf loc=&quot;post&quot;>helix</ce:inf> and the lipid <ce:italic>S</ce:italic><ce:inf loc=&quot;post&quot;>lipid</ce:inf> were calculated according to the formula:<display><formula><math altimg=&quot;si1.gif&quot;>S=<fr align=&quot;c&quot; shape=&quot;built&quot; style=&quot;s&quot;><nu>Ïµ<inf loc=&quot;post&quot;>x</inf><sup loc=&quot;post&quot;>2</sup>â??R<sup loc=&quot;post&quot;><rm>ATR</rm></sup>Ïµ<inf loc=&quot;post&quot;>y</inf><sup loc=&quot;post&quot;>2</sup>+Ïµ<inf loc=&quot;post&quot;>z</inf><sup loc=&quot;post&quot;>2</sup></nu><de>Ïµ<inf loc=&quot;post&quot;>x</inf><sup loc=&quot;post&quot;>2</sup>â??R<sup loc=&quot;post&quot;><rm>ATR</rm></sup>Ïµ<inf loc=&quot;post&quot;>y</inf><sup loc=&quot;post&quot;>2</sup>â??Ïµ<inf loc=&quot;post&quot;>z</inf><sup loc=&quot;post&quot;>2</sup></de></fr>Ã·<fr align=&quot;c&quot; shape=&quot;built&quot; style=&quot;s&quot;><nu>3<rm>cos</rm><sup loc=&quot;post&quot;>2</sup> Î±â??1</nu><de>2</de></fr></math></formula></display>where <ce:italic>R</ce:italic><ce:sup loc=&quot;post&quot;>ATR</ce:sup> is the dichroic ratio of amide I or amide A for <ce:italic>S</ce:italic><ce:inf loc=&quot;post&quot;>helix</ce:inf> and the dichroic ratio of the 2850 cm<ce:sup loc=&quot;post&quot;>â??1</ce:sup> band for <ce:italic>S</ce:italic><ce:inf loc=&quot;post&quot;>lipid</ce:inf>. The angle <ce:italic>Î±</ce:italic> is the angle between the transition dipole moment of the vibrational transition and the <ce:italic>z</ce:italic>-axis. The angle <ce:italic>Î±</ce:italic> is 90Â° for the lipid symmetric CH<ce:inf loc=&quot;post&quot;>2</ce:inf> stretching (2850 cm<ce:sup loc=&quot;post&quot;>â??1</ce:sup> band), 39Â° for the peptidic Cî??O bond and 29Â° for the Nâ??H bond <ce:cross-refs refid=&quot;BIB23 BIB24&quot;>[23,24]</ce:cross-refs>. The parameters <ce:italic>Ïµ<ce:inf loc=&quot;post&quot;>x</ce:inf></ce:italic>, <ce:italic>Ïµ<ce:inf loc=&quot;post&quot;>y</ce:inf></ce:italic> and <ce:italic>Ïµ<ce:inf loc=&quot;post&quot;>z</ce:inf></ce:italic> are the electric field components. Because the thickness of the film was estimated as being more than 20 Î¼m, whereas the amplitude of the evanescent wave decays (at 1/<ce:italic>Ïµ</ce:italic> of its initial value) after 1 Î¼m in a germanium plate, the values for these components are those given by <ce:cross-ref refid=&quot;BIB22&quot;>[22]</ce:cross-ref> according to a thick-film approximation. The contribution of <ce:italic>S</ce:italic><ce:inf loc=&quot;post&quot;>lipid</ce:inf> to <ce:italic>S</ce:italic><ce:inf loc=&quot;post&quot;>helix</ce:inf> was taken into account and the helix tilt <ce:italic>Î²</ce:italic> was calculated from <ce:italic>S</ce:italic><ce:inf loc=&quot;post&quot;>helixâ?²</ce:inf><display><formula><math altimg=&quot;si2.gif&quot;>S<inf loc=&quot;post&quot;><rm>helix</rm>â?²</inf>=<fr align=&quot;c&quot; shape=&quot;built&quot; style=&quot;s&quot;><nu>S<inf loc=&quot;post&quot;><rm>helix</rm></inf></nu><de>S<inf loc=&quot;post&quot;><rm>lipid</rm></inf></de></fr></math></formula></display>according to<display><formula><math altimg=&quot;si3.gif&quot;>S<inf loc=&quot;post&quot;><rm>helix</rm>â?²</inf>=<fr align=&quot;c&quot; shape=&quot;built&quot; style=&quot;s&quot;><nu>3(<rm>cos</rm><sup loc=&quot;post&quot;>2</sup> <it>Î²</it>)â??1</nu><de>2</de></fr></math></formula></display></ce:para><ce:para view=&quot;all&quot;>We note that when the dichroic ratio of the helix is obtained from the amide A dichroism and not the amide I dichroism, the precision in the determination of the helix tilt is increased, as the angle <ce:italic>Î±</ce:italic> for Nâ??H is smaller than for the Cî??O bond (see above), and consequently the possible range of dichroic ratios is wider. Also, the amide A band in these conditions, i.e. when the sample is exposed to D<ce:inf loc=&quot;post&quot;>2</ce:inf>O, originates only from the transmembrane Î±-helix that has not exchanged, therefore it only takes into account the contribution of peptides that have inserted properly in the membrane.</ce:para><ce:para view=&quot;all&quot;>Isotopic (H/D) exchange was calculated from the ratio amide II/amide I before and after H/D exchange using non-polarised spectra. These were obtained from the parallel (â?¥) and perpendicularly (â?¥) ATR polarised spectra, according to 1 (â?¥)+1.44 (â?¥), as described previously <ce:cross-ref refid=&quot;BIB25&quot;>[25]</ce:cross-ref>.</ce:para></ce:section></ce:section><ce:section view=&quot;all&quot;><ce:label>3</ce:label><ce:section-title>Results</ce:section-title><ce:section view=&quot;all&quot;><ce:label>3.1</ce:label><ce:section-title>DMPG membranes</ce:section-title><ce:para view=&quot;all&quot;><ce:cross-ref refid=&quot;FIG1&quot;>Fig. 1</ce:cross-ref><ce:float-anchor refid=&quot;FIG1&quot;></ce:float-anchor> (top panel) shows the amide I region for maculatin 1.1 after mixing the peptide with preformed DMPG liposomes. The amide I band is centred at 1657 cm<ce:sup loc=&quot;post&quot;>â??1</ce:sup>, indicating that the peptide adopts a predominantly Î±-helical structure <ce:cross-ref refid=&quot;BIB26&quot;>[26]</ce:cross-ref>. Both the original and the deconvoluted spectra (not shown) showed a small shoulder around 1640â??1630 cm<ce:sup loc=&quot;post&quot;>â??1</ce:sup>, indicating the presence of â?¼20% of Î²-structure. After D<ce:inf loc=&quot;post&quot;>2</ce:inf>O exposure (middle panel), an additional shoulder at 1675 cm<ce:sup loc=&quot;post&quot;>â??1</ce:sup> was observed in the amide I band, probably originating from Î²-turns <ce:cross-ref refid=&quot;BIB26&quot;>[26]</ce:cross-ref>. These non-helical structures could be due to extramembraneous parts of the peptide or from a fraction of molecules not fully inserted into the phospholipid membrane. The amide II is still present, although smaller, after 4 h exchange in D<ce:inf loc=&quot;post&quot;>2</ce:inf>O, indicating that part of the sample is protected from exchange and embedded in the membrane. The bottom panel in <ce:cross-ref refid=&quot;FIG1&quot;>Fig. 1</ce:cross-ref> shows that the amide A band, originating from amide Nâ??H stretching vibration, is also present. The results for the analogue P15A in DMPG membranes were similar (see <ce:cross-ref refid=&quot;FIG2&quot;>Fig. 2</ce:cross-ref><ce:float-anchor refid=&quot;FIG2&quot;></ce:float-anchor>).</ce:para><ce:para view=&quot;all&quot;>Examination of the ratio between non-polarised amide II and amide I before and after D<ce:inf loc=&quot;post&quot;>2</ce:inf>O exchange (not shown) revealed that approximately 70% of the maculatin 1.1 molecules were inserted in the membrane (the exchange was less than 30% of the amide NH protons). For the analogue, the percentage of non-exchanged amide groups was 65%, therefore, this peptide also inserts into the membranes of preformed DMPG liposomes under our experimental conditions.</ce:para><ce:para view=&quot;all&quot;><ce:cross-ref refid=&quot;TBL1&quot;>Table 1</ce:cross-ref><ce:float-anchor refid=&quot;TBL1&quot;></ce:float-anchor> shows the dichroic ratios obtained under these different conditions and the helix tilts obtained as described in <ce:cross-ref refid=&quot;SEC2&quot;>Section 2</ce:cross-ref>. For maculatin 1.1, when bulk water was removed (<ce:cross-ref refid=&quot;FIG1&quot;>Fig. 1</ce:cross-ref>, top) the amide I band dichroism (3.0Â±0.1) indicates that the peptide is oriented 9Â° from the membrane normal. Interestingly, after hydration in D<ce:inf loc=&quot;post&quot;>2</ce:inf>O, the dichroism of the amide I was lower (2.8Â±0.1, see <ce:cross-ref refid=&quot;TBL1&quot;>Table 1</ce:cross-ref>), giving a helix tilt of 27Â°. The helix tilt in this case, however, was calculated with the more reliable amide A dichroism (2.95Â±0.1) which gives a helix tilt of 35Â°. The dichroic ratio of the band at 2850 cm<ce:sup loc=&quot;post&quot;>â??1</ce:sup>, that originates from the methylene CH<ce:inf loc=&quot;post&quot;>2</ce:inf> stretching from the lipid, was typically 1.2 in DMPG.</ce:para><ce:para view=&quot;all&quot;>For the analogue, the dichroic ratio of the amide I band was found to be lower than for maculatin 1.1, both before and after D<ce:inf loc=&quot;post&quot;>2</ce:inf>O hydration (see <ce:cross-ref refid=&quot;TBL1&quot;>Table 1</ce:cross-ref>, second row). The amide A dichroism when the sample was hydrated in D<ce:inf loc=&quot;post&quot;>2</ce:inf>O was also lower (2.25Â±0.04) than for maculatin 1.1. The helix tilt of the analogue therefore was greater than that for maculatin 1.1 (46Â° under D<ce:inf loc=&quot;post&quot;>2</ce:inf>O hydration).</ce:para><ce:para view=&quot;all&quot;>Note, however, that these values for the helix tilt could be even lower, i.e. closer to the membrane normal, as this calculations do not take into account randomly oriented peptide <ce:cross-ref refid=&quot;BIB27&quot;>[27]</ce:cross-ref>.</ce:para></ce:section><ce:section view=&quot;all&quot;><ce:label>3.2</ce:label><ce:section-title>DMPC membranes</ce:section-title><ce:para view=&quot;all&quot;>In similar experiments using zwitterionic DMPC membranes, it was observed that both maculatin 1.1 and the analogue P15A showed little or no Î±-helical structure. The sample contained significant amounts of Î²-structure and -turns (&gt;30% each), and the width of the amide I was larger than that observed for the samples in DMPG (data not shown). In addition, the amide I dichroic ratio corresponding to the region between 1670 and 1645 cm<ce:sup loc=&quot;post&quot;>â??1</ce:sup>, both in the hydrated sample and the one before hydration of approximately 2, is consistent with this. After D<ce:inf loc=&quot;post&quot;>2</ce:inf>O exposure, only â?¼5% of maculatin 1.1 was protected from exchange, indicating that 95% of the sample was not inserted in the membrane, although for the 5% of the sample that did not exchange in D<ce:inf loc=&quot;post&quot;>2</ce:inf>O, the helix tilt was estimated to be less than 17Â° to the membrane normal, with an amide A dichroic ratio of 5 (not shown). The P15A analogue showed a similar low degree of protection against exchange (&lt;5%), but the small fraction that did not exchange, yielded results, <ce:italic>R</ce:italic><ce:inf loc=&quot;post&quot;>AI</ce:inf>(<ce:italic>Î²</ce:italic>)=1.55 (82Â°) and <ce:italic>R</ce:italic><ce:inf loc=&quot;post&quot;>AA</ce:inf>(<ce:italic>Î²</ce:italic>)=1.75 (65Â°), which suggest that the non-exchanged part of the sample was not inserted in, but instead lying parallel to, the membrane surface.</ce:para></ce:section></ce:section><ce:section view=&quot;all&quot;><ce:label>4</ce:label><ce:section-title>Discussion</ce:section-title><ce:para view=&quot;all&quot;>We have not reconstituted peptide and bilayer simultaneously, but added peptide to preformed liposomes, in an attempt to mimic the processes which occur when peptide binds to an intact bacterial membrane.</ce:para><ce:para view=&quot;all&quot;>The main conclusion derived from this work is that the helix tilt of maculatin 1.1, particularly in DMPG membranes, supports a mechanism of action in which the peptide disrupts the membranes by forming a pore. The helix tilt varied with hydration, being more tilted when the sample was fully hydrated with D<ce:inf loc=&quot;post&quot;>2</ce:inf>O. We assume that the value obtained using a hydrated sample should be closer to the conditions encountered by the peptide in biological conditions. Therefore, the helix tilt obtained here is 35Â°, incompatible with the â??carpetâ?? mechanism of action, in which the peptides would orient parallel to the membrane surface, i.e. with a tilt of 90Â° to the bilayer normal.</ce:para><ce:para view=&quot;all&quot;>We note that a comparison between maculatin 1.1 and the peptide melittin, a channel forming peptide <ce:cross-ref refid=&quot;BIB14&quot;>[14]</ce:cross-ref>, reveals a remarkably similar sequence homology (see <ce:cross-ref refid=&quot;TBL2&quot;>Table 2</ce:cross-ref><ce:float-anchor refid=&quot;TBL2&quot;></ce:float-anchor>). Both peptides are rich in hydrophobic residues at their N-termini and both have a central proline residue which is seven residues apart from the lysine. It is possible that the proline-induced kink in the peptide causes partial penetration of the peptide into the phospholipid bilayer upon binding to the bacterial membrane surface, which facilitates complete insertion of the entire peptide into the bilayer.</ce:para><ce:para view=&quot;all&quot;>NMR studies have shown that both maculatin 1.1 and its P15A analogue are Î±-helical, but the natural peptide has a central proline kink, resulting in the formation of an amphipathic helix in the presence of phospholipid micelles (<ce:cross-ref refid=&quot;FIG3&quot;>Fig. 3</ce:cross-ref><ce:float-anchor refid=&quot;FIG3&quot;></ce:float-anchor>, left) <ce:cross-ref refid=&quot;BIB16&quot;>[16]</ce:cross-ref>. The P15A analogue, however, forms a less-amphipathic Î±-helix (<ce:cross-ref refid=&quot;FIG3&quot;>Fig. 3</ce:cross-ref>, right). Binding studies using a surface plasmon resonance biosensor, together with a vesicle-capture sensor chip, revealed that maculatin 1.1 bound strongly to the anionic DMPG vesicles but not to the zwitterionic DMPC vesicles, while the P15A analogue did not significantly bind to either DMPG or DMPC vesicles (Chia et al., unpublished results). Somewhat unexpectedly, we found that the maculatin 1.1 analogue, which lacks antibiotic activity <ce:cross-ref refid=&quot;BIB16&quot;>[16]</ce:cross-ref>, also inserted perpendicularly into preformed DMPG vesicles, although its helix tilt was higher than that of maculatin 1.1. However, we stress that in biological conditions, the lipid:peptide ratio on the membrane surface is likely to be much lower than in our study. This may induce the P15A analogue to insert into DMPG membranes under our experimental conditions. Also, it is possible that substitution of the proline residue promotes peptide aggregation in solution and hence interferes with its membrane binding capability <ce:cross-ref refid=&quot;BIB29&quot;>[29]</ce:cross-ref>.</ce:para><ce:para view=&quot;all&quot;>The fact that the P15A analogue has a higher tilt than maculatin in DMPG suggests that, although insertion is observed in our special experimental conditions, a different inter-helical interaction is likely to occur when the analogue inserts. This is expected, as the mutation P15A changes the side chain distribution around the helix axis (<ce:cross-ref refid=&quot;FIG3&quot;>Fig. 3</ce:cross-ref>). Consistent with this, it has been shown by conductance experiments involving melittin and its P14A analogue that the latter suffered a diminished capability to form transmembrane channels <ce:cross-ref refid=&quot;BIB28&quot;>[28]</ce:cross-ref>.</ce:para><ce:para view=&quot;all&quot;>Using DMPC vesicles, only a very small fraction of maculatin 1.1 was found to insert almost perpendicularly into DMPC membranes. We have shown therefore that DMPG is a much more suitable lipid for peptide insertion, as compared to DMPC. First, we have found that anionic membranes (DMPG) induce a more Î±-helical structure in maculatin and its analogue, which then precipitate membrane insertion. In contrast, zwitterionic membranes (DMPC) induce a less Î±-helical structure, with substantial contributions of Î²-turns, Î²-structure and disordered structure. Second, the percentage of sample protected against exchange in DMPC (&lt;5%) is very small compared with the DMPG membranes (&gt;60%).</ce:para><ce:para view=&quot;all&quot;>Overall, the experimental results suggest that maculatin 1.1 exerts its membrane lytic action via the â??channelâ?? mechanism. The lack of insertion of maculatin 1.1 in DMPC is probably sufficient to explain why this peptide shows a lack of activity against Gram-negative bacteria, although other factors such as the presence of the outer layer can also contribute. Whether channel formation is triggered by self-assembly of peptide monomers on the membrane or if the peptide reaches the membrane already assembled is beyond the scope of this study.
